concept: Use std::map to build dictionaries, count frequencies, and aggregate values.

challenges.title: Number Frequencies
challenges.description: Given N and N integers, print the frequency of each distinct number in increasing order of the number. Each line must be: number count.
challenges.inputDescription: First line: N. Second line: N integers.
challenges.outputDescription: Multiple lines of 'number count' in sorted order.

challenges.title: Word Frequencies
challenges.description: Given a single line of text, print words and their frequencies sorted lexicographically by word. Each line: word count.
challenges.outputDescription: Multiple lines: word count in lexicographic order of word.
examples:
Input:
hi hi what is hi

Output:
hi 3
is 1
what 1

challenges.title: Synonym Dictionary
challenges.description: You are given N pairs of synonyms (two words each). Then you are given a single word. Print its synonym. It is guaranteed that the word appears in exactly one pair.
challenges.inputDescription: First line: N. Next N lines: two words per line. Last line: query word.
challenges.outputDescription: The synonym of the query word.
examples:
Input:
3
big large
smart clever
fast quick
clever

Output:
smart

challenges.title: Election Results
challenges.description: You are given records of votes for candidates. Each record has candidate_name and votes (integer). For each candidate, sum total votes and print results sorted by candidate name.
challenges.inputDescription: First line: N. Next N lines: name votes.
challenges.outputDescription: Lines of 'name totalVotes' sorted lexicographically by name.
examples: Example: Alice 10, Bob 5, Alice 3 -> Alice 13, Bob 5.

challenges.title: Most Frequent Word
challenges.description: Given n lines of text, find the word that occurs most frequently. If several words have the same highest frequency, print the lexicographically smallest one.
challenges.inputDescription: First line: n. Next n lines: text.
challenges.outputDescription: Single word: most frequent (break ties by lexicographic order).
examples: Example: 'hi hi what is hi' -> hi

challenges.title: File Access Rights
challenges.description: You are given access rights for files. For each file you know which operations are allowed: 'R' (read), 'W' (write), 'X' (execute). Then you get M queries of operation and file. For each query, print OK if operation is allowed, otherwise Access denied.
challenges.inputDescription: First line: N. Next N lines: fileName followed by operations. Next line: M. Next M lines: operation fileName.
challenges.outputDescription: M lines: OK or Access denied.
examples: Example based on standard access rights problem.

challenges.title: Cities and Countries
challenges.description: Given a mapping from countries to their cities, then queries of city names, print the country for each city.
challenges.inputDescription: First line: N. For each of N lines: countryName k city1 city2 ... cityk. Then line Q, then Q city names.
challenges.outputDescription: For each query city, print its country.
examples:
Example: India 2 Delhi Mumbai
Q=1, city=Delhi -> India

challenges.title: Word Frequencies by Popularity
challenges.description: Given n lines of text, print all distinct words sorted by descending frequency; for equal frequency, sort lexicographically ascending. Print one word per line.
challenges.inputDescription: First line: n. Next n lines: text.
challenges.outputDescription: Words, one per line, sorted by (-frequency, word).
examples: Example: hi hi what is is -> hi, is, what (each on its own line).

challenges.title: Student Total Scores
challenges.description: Given N lines with student name and score, sum scores per student and print 'name totalScore' on separate lines sorted by name.
challenges.inputDescription: First line: N. Next N lines: string name, int score.
challenges.outputDescription: Lines 'name totalScore' sorted lexicographically by name.
examples: Example: Ram 10, Kiran 5, Ram 7 -> Kiran 5, Ram 17.

challenges.title: Replace Words with Synonyms
challenges.description: Given N synonym pairs (a b). Then a sentence. For each word in the sentence, if it appears as a or b in any pair, replace it with its synonym; otherwise keep it unchanged.
challenges.inputDescription: First line: N. Next N lines: a b. Last line: sentence.
challenges.outputDescription: New sentence after replacing words by synonyms.
examples: Example: pair: big large; sentence: big cat -> large cat.
